Fun with the Track 3 diabetes app

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎04-01-2014 02:22 PM

So I log in my diabetes app my diet, exercise, meter readings and morning weight.  I've been noticing a few patterns lately about my weight (which seems to be on the upswing) and days of week.  I thought I'd use the feature of the app to export data to an Excel file and write a quick perl script to parse it.  Sure enough my Sunday numbers are higher than any other day:

 

Sunday --- 102.48
Non Sunday --- 91.52

 

It might be that I test more on Sundays because I freak out about the higher numbers, but still that's valid.  Note that those numbers aren't my real average as I've standardized my diet so I don't test after a lot of meals if I know pretty much what they're going to do.

 

I also broke it out by month and saw that Feb was slightly lower than Jan and March was slightly lower than Feb.  That's always good to see.

 

However, the reason why I did this was that I was freaking out about my weight.  I'm feeling it creep up in my morning weigh ins and I'm getting a bit worried.  Here's where I can mock myself.  My morning averages:

 

March: 168.24
Feb: 166.95
Jan:165.60
Dec: 166.02
Nov: 166.62
Oct: 166.94
Sep: 167.75
Aug: 168.14

 

So yes, I put on some weight, but it looks like it's under 3 pounds from my low (which was worrying me a bit).  Yeah I don't like the gain and I'm going to keep my eye on it, but I'm stunned at how little it is.  Looks like I don't have to make the changes in my diet that I've been considering after all.  

 

The moral of this story is to track and use the data.  Sometimes the news it gives you isn't as bad as you feared.   

*********************************
twitter.com/zzyzx

Diagnosed 2/13 with an 8.0
A1C 5/13: 5.2!
8/13 5.2 again.
2/14: 5.4 Came after relaxing my diet quite a bit, but increasing my exercise intensity.
10/14 5.0!!

30-90 minutes of intense cardio every day. 15 minutes of difficult weight lifting 6 days a week. 150-200 g of carbs a day, never more than 50 at a sitting. vegetarian.

‎04-02-2014 01:22 AM

Is Sunday the day you don't exercise?  Your weight gain is very slight ZedZed, but I guess you are thinking it might continue to rise if you don't stop it now.  Or, could you weigh more due to being more muscular?  The intensity of your exercise program is bound to have an affect on your weight...muscle always weighs more, as I am sure you know.  I use a site online and do download it to Excel...it contains all of my readings, everything I have eaten and all the nutritional values.  It helps me to keep this diary of sorts.  I weigh once a month at my doctor's office...so only those numbers are not in my program.  Interesting ZedZed!

"The road to success is always under construction."
- Lily Tomlin

01/2013 - diagnosed with T2 and hypothyroidism
A1c - 7.2
04/16/2013 - A1c 6.1
07/24/2013 - A1c 5.8 (bayernow)
09/21/2013 - A1c 5.6 (bayernow)
10/10/2013 - A1c 5.7
04/30/2014 - A1c 5.5
12/10/2014 - A1c 5.4
500 mg Metformin/1 per day
Low Carb
Beginning weight - 183
08/27/2013 - 143
10/03/2013 - 141
12/05/2013 - 138
12/10/2014 - 144
Blood Pressure 12/05/2013 - 118/60
Blood Pressure 02/2014 - 106/54 (too low, medication cut to maintenance dose)
Blood Pressure 04/29/2014 - 110/65
Blood Pressure 12/10/2014 - 105/72
T2 paternal grandmother, father, two sisters, my deceased husband, and my ex husband

‎04-02-2014 07:32 AM

Saturday is the day I don't lift (still exercise) so I think that's why my Sunday numbers are higher.

 

Definitely getting a bit... worried... about my weight numbers just because they're making no sense.  I'm not eating more than I used to, I've added a 3 mile walk with my wife in addition to my gym sessions, and still I'm seeing things creep up over the last week and an half.  I wouldn't care if it weren't for the fact that my weight issue was a sign that my diabetes was kicking in.

‎04-02-2014 10:07 AM

You weigh yourself that often?

 

Do you know the accuracy of your scales?  Chances are it's +/- 5% or so.  That would mean that your readings are not as far apart as you think.

 

One large glass of water (1 pint) weights approx. 1 pound.  Just being a little dehydrated can make you weigh a lot less.  That's why high school and college wrestlers sweat their weight down before meets so they can compete in lower weight classes.

 

I don't weigh myself very often.  I think I just enjoy the surprise factor.

 

Type 2 - complicated by surgery for pancreatic cancer

‎04-02-2014 11:32 AM

I'm completely obsessive.  I weigh myself like 5 times a day because I'm fascinated by how it fluctuates

 

...it's the counter to letting it slack and being shocked when I finally went to the doctor and discovered what my weight and A1C was.  I tend to be a person of extremes.

 

 

It's worrying me that I'm gaining for no reason just because anything different about my body worries me.  Still though, some of that is muscle, my levels are still fine, and what I need to remember is that even if I gain a pound a month:  

 

(1) it'll probably reach a new equilibrium at some point

 

and 

 

(2) It would take me 7 more years to get back to my start weight which is plenty of time to adjust if I need to.

*********************************

Diagnosed 2/13 with an 8.0
A1C 5/13: 5.2!
8/13 5.2 again.

Shirl

This community. Keep moving; graze on bit of protein and lots of veggies; meds. No wheat, rice, or soy.
BG's 70-120. Avg AM BP 125/65. BMI 22.2-23.2
Still learning

Hubby: Not diabetic

Anemia, Colostomy, COPD, weak heart valve, low BP
Colo vesicle fistula (hole bladder to colon), can't be repaired due to radiation damage

Life sure isn't boring.
